sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Shall I deny you? no: farewell, my lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Farewell, my Desdemona: I'll come to thee straight.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Emilia, come. Be as your fancies teach you;
What e'er you be, I am obedient. Exeunt Desdemona and Emilia.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Excellent wretch! Perdition catch my soul,
But I do love thee! and when I love thee not,
Chaos is come again.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My noble lord, —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What dost thou say, Iago?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Did Michael Cassio, when you wooed my lady,
Know of your love?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: He did, from first to last: why dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: But for a satisfaction of my thought;
No further harm.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Why of thy thought, Iago?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I did not think he had been acquainted with her.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O, yes; and went between us very oft.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Indeed! ay, indeed: discern'st thou aught in that?
Is he not honest?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Honest, my lord!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Honest! ay, honest.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My lord, for aught I know.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What dost thou think?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Think, my lord!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Think my lord! By heaven, thou echo'st me,
As if there were some monster in thy thought
Too hideous to be shown. Thou dost mean something:
I heard thee say even now, thou likedst not that,
When Cassio left my wife: what didst not like?
And when I told thee he was of my counsel
In my whole course of wooing, thou criedst “Indeed!”
And didst contract and purse thy brow together,
As if thou then hadst shut up in thy brain
Some horrible conceit: if thou dost love me,
Show me thy thought.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My lord, you know I love you.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I think thou dost;
And, for I know thou'rt full of love and honesty,
And weigh'st thy words before thou givest them breath,
Therefore these stops of thine fright me the more:
For such things in a false disloyal knave
Are tricks of custom, but in a man that's just
They're close dilations, working from the heart
That passion cannot rule.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: For Michael Cassio
I dare be sworn I think that he is honest.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I think so too.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Men should be what they seem;
Or those that be not, would they might seem none!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Certain, men should be what they seem.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Why, then, I think Cassio's an honest man.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Nay, yet there's more in this:
I prithee, speak to me as to thy thinkings,
As thou dost ruminate, and give thy worst of thoughts
The worst of words.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Good my lord, pardon me:
Though I am bound to every act of duty,
I am not bound to that all slaves are free to.
Utter my thoughts? Why, say they are vile and false;
As where's that palace whereinto foul things
Sometimes intrude not? who has that breast so pure,
But some uncleanly apprehensions
Keep leets and law-days and in sessions sit
With meditations lawful?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Thou dost conspire against thy friend, Iago,
If thou but think'st him wronged and makest his ear
A stranger to thy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I do beseech you —
Though I perchance am vicious in my guess,
As, I confess, it is my nature's plague
To spy into abuses, and oft my jealousy
Shapes faults that are not — that your wisdom then,
From one that so imperfectly conjects,
Would take no notice, nor build yourself a trouble
Out of his scattering and unsure observance.
It were not for your quiet nor your good,
Nor for my manhood, honesty, and wisdom
To let you know my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: 'Zounds! What dost thou mean?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Good name in man and woman, dear my lord,
Is the immediate jewel of their souls:
Who steals my purse steals trash; 'tis something, nothing;
'Twas mine, 'tis his, and has been slave to thousands;
But he that filches from me my good name
Robs me of that which not enriches him
And makes me poor indeed.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: By heaven, I'll know thy thoughts.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: You cannot, if my heart were in your hand;
Nor shall not, whilst 'tis in my custody.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: O, beware, my lord, of jealousy;
It is the green-eyed monster which doth mock
The meat it feeds on: that cuckold lives in bliss
Who, certain of his fate, loves not his wronger;
But, O, what damned minutes tells he o'er
Who dotes, yet doubts, suspects, yet strongly loves!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O misery!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Poor and content is rich and rich enough,
But riches fineless is as poor as winter
To him that ever fears he shall be poor.
Good God, the souls of all my tribe defend
From jealousy!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Why, why is this?
Think'st thou I'ld make a life of jealousy,
To follow still the changes of the moon
With fresh suspicions? No; to be once in doubt
Is once to be resolved: exchange me for a goat,
When I shall turn the business of my soul
To such exsufflicate and blown surmises,
Matching thy inference. 'Tis not to make me jealous
To say my wife is fair, — feeds well, loves company,
Is free of speech, sings, plays and dances well;
Where virtue is, these are more virtuous:
Nor from mine own weak merits will I draw
The smallest fear or doubt of her revolt;
For she had eyes, and chose me. No, Iago;
I'll see before I doubt; when I doubt, prove;
And on the proof, there is no more but this, —
Away at once with love or jealousy!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I am glad of this; for now I shall have reason
To show the love and duty that I bear you
With franker spirit: therefore, as I am bound,
Receive it from me. I speak not yet of proof.
Look to your wife; observe her well with Cassio;
Wear your eyes thus, not jealous nor secure:
I would not have your free and noble nature,
Out of self-bounty, be abused; look to't:
I know our country disposition well;
In Venice they do let God see the pranks
They dare not show their husbands; their best conscience
Is not to leave't undone, but keep't unknown.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Dost thou say so?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: She did deceive her father, marrying you;
And when she seemed to shake and fear your looks,
She loved them most.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: And so she did.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Why, go to then;
She that, so young, could give out such a seeming,
To seel her father's eyes up close as oak —
He thought 'twas witchcraft — but I am much to blame;
I humbly do beseech you of your pardon
For too much loving you.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I am bound to thee for ever.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I see this hath a little dashed your spirits.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Not a jot, not a jot.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I' faith, I fear it has.
I hope you will consider what is spoke
Comes from my love. But I do see y' are moved:
I am to pray you not to strain my speech
To grosser issues nor to larger reach
Than to suspicion.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I will not.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Should you do so, my lord,
My speech should fall into such vile success
Which my thoughts aimed not. Cassio's my worthy friend —
My lord, I see y' are moved.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: No, not much moved:
I do not think but Desdemona's honest.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Long live she so! and long live you to think so!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: And yet, how nature erring, from itself, —

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Ay, there's the point: as — to be bold with you —
Not to affect many proposed matches
Of her own clime, complexion, and degree,
Whereto we see in all things nature tends —
Foh! one may smell in such a will most rank,
Foul disproportions, thoughts unnatural.
But pardon me; I do not in position
Distinctly speak of her; though I may fear
Her will, recoiling to her better judgement,
May fall to match you with her country forms
And happily repent.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Farewell, farewell:
If more thou dost perceive, let me know more;
Set on thy wife to observe: leave me, Iago.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My lord, I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Why did I marry? This honest creature doubtless
Sees and knows more, much more, than he unfolds.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My lord, I would I might entreat your honour
To scan this thing no further; leave it to time:
Although 'tis fit that Cassio have his place,
For, sure, he fills it up with great ability,
Yet, if you please to hold him off awhile,
You shall by that perceive him and his means:
Note, if your lady strain his entertainment
With any strong or vehement importunity;
Much will be seen in that. In the meantime,
Let me be thought too busy in my fears —
As worthy cause I have to fear I am —
And hold her free, I do beseech your honour.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Fear not my government.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I once more take my leave. Exit.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: This fellow's of exceeding honesty,
And knows all qualities, with a learned spirit,
Of human dealings. If I do prove her haggard,
Though that her jesses — were my dear heartstrings,
I'ld whistle her off and let her down the wind,
To prey at fortune. Haply, for I am black
And have not those soft parts of conversation
That chamberers have, or for I am declined
Into the vale of years, — yet that's not much —
She's gone. I am abused; and my relief
Must be to loathe her. O curse of marriage,
That we can call these delicate creatures ours,
And not their appetites! I had rather be a toad,
And live upon the vapour of a dungeon,
Than keep a corner in the thing I love
For others' uses. Yet, 'tis the plague of great ones;
Prerogatived are they less than the base;
'Tis destiny unshunnable, like death:
Even then this forked plague is fated to us
When we do quicken. Look where she comes. Re-enter DESDEMONA and EMILIA.
If she be false, O, then heaven mocks itself!
I'll not believe't.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: How now, my dear Othello!
Your dinner, and the generous islanders
By you invited, do attend your presence.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I am to blame.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Why do you speak so faintly?
Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I have a pain upon my forehead here.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: 'Faith, that's with watching; 'twill away again:
Let me but bind it hard, within this hour
It will be well.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Your napkin is too little: He puts the handkerchief from him; and it drops.
Let it alone. Come, I'll go in with you.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I am very sorry that you are not well. Exeunt Othello and Desdemona.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I am glad I have found this napkin:
This was her first remembrance from the Moor:
My wayward husband hath a hundred times
wooed me to steal it; but she so loves the token,
For he conjured her she should ever keep it,
That she reserves it evermore about her
To kiss and talk to. I'll have the work ta'en out,
And give't Iago: what he will do with it
Heaven knows, not I;
I nothing but to please his fantasy. Re-enter IAGO.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: How now! what do you here alone?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Do not you chide; I have a thing for you.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: You have a thing for me? it is a common thing —

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: To have a foolish wife.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O, is that all? What will you give me now
For that same handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: What handkerchief!
Why, that the Moor first gave to Desdemona;
That which so often you did bid me steal.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Hast stol'n it from her?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: No, 'faith; she let it drop by negligence,
And, to the advantage, I, being here, took't up.
Look, here 'tis.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: A good wench; give it me.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: What will you do with't, that you have been so earnest
To have me filch it?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Why, what is that to you?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: If it be not for some purpose of import,
Give't me again: poor lady, she'll run mad
When she shall lack it.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Be not acknown on't; I have use for it.
Go, leave me. Exit Emilia.
I will in Cassio's lodging lose this napkin,
And let him find it. Trifles light as air
Are to the jealous confirmations strong
As proofs of holy writ: this may do something.
The Moor already changes with my poison:
Dangerous conceits are, in their natures, poisons,
Which at the first are scarce found to distaste,
But with a little act upon the blood,
Burn like the mines of sulphur. I did say so:
Look, where he comes! Re-enter OTHELLO. Not poppy, nor mandragora,
Nor all the drowsy syrups of the world,
Shall ever medicine thee to that sweet sleep
Which thou owedst yesterday.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ha! ha! false to me?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Why, how now, general! no more of that.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Avaunt! be gone! thou hast set me on the rack:
I swear 'tis better to be much abused
Than but to know't a little.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: How now, my lord!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What sense had I in her stol'n hours of lust?
I saw't not, thought it not, it harmed not me:
I slept the next night well, fed well, was free and merry;
I found not Cassio's kisses on her lips:
He that is robbed, not wanting what is stol'n,
Let him not know't, and he's not robbed at all.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I am sorry to hear this.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I had been happy, if the general camp,
Pioners and all, had tasted her sweet body,
So I had nothing known. O, now, for ever
Farewell the tranquil mind! farewell content!
Farewell the plumed troops, and the big wars,
That makes ambition virtue! O, farewell!
Farewell the neighing steed, and the shrill trump,
The spirit-stirring drum, the ear-piercing fife,
The royal banner, and all quality,
Pride, pomp and circumstance of glorious war!
And, O you mortal engines, whose rude throats
The immortal Jove's dread clamours counterfeit,
Farewell! Othello's occupation's gone!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Is't possible, my lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Villain, be sure thou prove my love a whore,
Be sure of it; give me the ocular proof;
Or, by the worth of mine eternal soul,
Thou hadst been better have been born a dog
Than answer my waked wrath!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Is't come to this?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Make me to see't; or, at the least, so prove it,
That the probation bear no hinge nor loop
To hang a doubt on; or woe upon thy life!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My noble lord, —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: If thou dost slander her and torture me,
Never pray more; abandon all remorse;
On horror's head horrors accumulate;
Do deeds to make heaven weep, all earth amazed;
For nothing canst thou to damnation add
Greater than that.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: O grace! O heaven forgive me!
Are you a man? have you a soul or sense?
God buy you; take mine office. O wretched fool,
That lovest to make thine honesty a vice!
O monstrous world! Take note, take note, O world,
To be direct and honest is not safe.
I thank you for this profit; and from hence
I'll love no friend, sith love breeds such offence.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Nay, stay: thou shouldst be honest.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I should be wise, for honesty's a fool
And loses that it works for.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: By the world,
I think my wife be honest and think she is not;
I think that thou art just and think thou art not.
I'll have some proof. Her name, that was as fresh
As Dian's visage, is now begrimed and black
As mine own face. If there be cords, or knives,
Poison, or fire, or suffocating streams,
I'll not endure it. Would I were satisfied!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I see, sir, you are eaten up with passion:
I do repent me that I put it to you.
You would be satisfied?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Would! nay, and I will.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: And may: but, how? how satisfied, my lord?
Would you, the supervisor, grossly gape on —
Behold her topped?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Death and damnation! O!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: It were a tedious difficulty, I think,
To bring them to that prospect: damn them then,
If ever mortal eyes do see them bolster
More than their own! What then? how then?
What shall I say? Where's satisfaction?
It is impossible you should see this,
Were they as prime as goats, as hot as monkeys,
As salt as wolves in pride, and fools as gross
As ignorance made drunk. But yet, I say,
If imputation and strong circumstances,
Which lead directly to the door of truth,
Will give you satisfaction, you might have't.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Give me a living reason she's disloyal.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I do not like the office:
But, sith, I am entered in this cause so far,
Pricked to't by foolish honesty and love,
I will go on. I lay with Cassio lately;
And, being troubled with a raging tooth,
I could not sleep.
There are a kind of men so loose of soul,
That in their sleeps will mutter their affairs:
One of this kind is Cassio:
In sleep I heard him say “Sweet Desdemona,
Let us be wary, let us hide our loves;
And then, sir, would he gripe and wring my hand,
Cry “O sweet creature!” then kiss me hard,
As if he plucked up kisses by the roots
That grew upon my lips; then laid his leg
Over my thigh, and sighed, and kissed; and then
Cried “Cursed fate that gave thee to the Moor!”

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O monstrous! monstrous!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Nay, this was but his dream.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: But this denoted a forgone conclusion:
'Tis a shrewd doubt, though it be but a dream.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: And this may help to thicken other proofs
That do demonstrate thinly.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I'll tear her all to pieces.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Nay, yet be wise: yet we see nothing done;
She may be honest yet. Tell me but this,
Have you not sometimes seen a handkerchief
Spotted with strawberries in your wife's hand?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I gave her such a one; 'twas my first gift.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I know not that: but such a handkerchief —
I am sure it was your wife's — did I to-day
See Cassio wipe his beard with.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: If it be that, —

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: If it be that, or any that was hers,
It speaks against her with the other proofs.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O, that the slave had forty thousand lives!
One is too poor, too weak for my revenge.
Now do I see 'tis true. Look here, Iago;
All my fond love thus do I blow to heaven.
'Tis gone.
Arise, black vengeance, from the hollow hell
Yield up, O love, thy crown and hearted throne
To tyrannous hate! Swell, bosom, with thy fraught,
For 'tis of aspics' tongues!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Yet be content.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O, blood, blood, blood!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Patience, I say, your mind perhaps may change.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Never, Iago. Like to the Pontic sea,
Whose icy current and compulsive course
Ne'er feels retiring ebb, but keeps due on
To the Propontic and the Hellespont,
Even so my bloody thoughts, with violent pace,
Shall ne'er look back, ne'er ebb to humble love,
Till that a capable and wide revenge
Swallow them up. Now, by yond marble heaven, Kneels
In the due reverence of a sacred vow
I here engage my words.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Do not rise yet. Kneels
Witness, you ever-burning lights above,
You elements that clip us round about,
Witness that here Iago doth give up
The execution of his wit, hands, heart,
To wronged Othello's service! Let him command,
And to obey shall be in me remorse,
What bloody business ever. They rise.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I greet thy love,
Not with vain thanks, but with acceptance bounteous,
And will upon the instant put thee to't:
Within these three days let me hear thee say
That Cassio's not alive.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My friend is dead; 'tis done at your request:
But let her live.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Damn her, lewd minx! O, damn her, damn her!
Come, go with me apart; I will withdraw,
To furnish me with some swift means of death
For the fair devil. Now art thou my lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I am your own for ever. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: Do you know, sirrah, where Lieutenant Cassio lies?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I dare not say he lies any where.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: Why, man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: He's a soldier, and for me to say a soldier lies, 'tis
stabbing.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: Go to: where lodges he?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: To tell you where he lodges, is to tell you where I
lie.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: Can any thing be made of this?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I know not where he lodges, and for me to devise
a lodging and say he lies here or he lies there, were
to lie in mine own throat.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: Can you inquire him out, and be edified by report?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: I will catechize the world for him; that is, make
questions, and by them answer.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: Seek him, bid him come hither: tell him I have
moved my lord on his behalf, and hope all will be
well.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.ab: To do this is within the compass of man's wit; and
therefore I will attempt the doing it.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Where should I lose the handkerchief, Emilia?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I know not, madam.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Believe me, I had rather have lost my purse
Full of crusadoes: and, but my noble Moor
Is true of mind and made of no such baseness
As jealous creatures are, it were enough
To put him to ill thinking.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Is he not jealous?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Who, he? I think the sun where he was born
Drew all such humours from him.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Look, where he comes.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I will not leave him now till Cassio
Be called to him. Enter OTHELLO. How is't with you, my lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Well, my good lady. Aside
O, hardness to dissemble! —
How do you, Desdemona?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Well, my good lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Give me your hand: this hand is moist, my lady.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: It yet hath felt no age nor known no sorrow.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: This argues fruitfulness and liberal heart:
Hot, hot, and moist: this hand of yours requires
A sequester from liberty, fasting and prayer,
Much castigation, exercise devout;
For here's a young and sweating devil here,
That commonly rebels. 'Tis a good hand,
A frank one.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: You may, indeed, say so;
For 'twas that hand that gave away my heart.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: A liberal hand: the hearts of old gave hands;
But our new heraldry is hands, not hearts.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I cannot speak of this. Come now, your promise.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What promise, chuck?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I have sent to bid Cassio come speak with you.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I have a salt and sorry rheum offends me;
Lend me thy handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Here, my lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That which I gave you.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I have it not about me.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Not?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: No, indeed, my lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That's a fault. That handkerchief
Did an Egyptian to my mother give;
She was a charmer, and could almost read
The thoughts of people: she told her, while she kept it,
'Twould make her amiable and subdue my father
Entirely to her love, but if she lost it
Or made a gift of it, my father's eye
Should hold her loathed and his spirits should hunt
After new fancies: she, dying, gave it me;
And bid me, when my fate would have me wived,
To give it her. I did so: and take heed on't;
Make it a darling like your precious eye;
To lose't or give't away were such perdition
As nothing else could match.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: 'Tis true: there's magic in the web of it:
A sibyl, that had numbered in the world
The sun to course two hundred compasses,
In her prophetic fury sewed the work;
The worms were hallowed that did breed the silk;
And it was dyed in mummy which the skilful
Conserved of maidens' hearts.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I' faith! is't true?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Most veritable; therefore look to't well.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Then would to God that I had never seen't!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ha! wherefore?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Why do you speak so startingly and rash?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Is't lost? is't gone? speak, is't out o' the way?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Heaven bless us!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Say you?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: It is not lost; but what an if it were?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I say, it is not lost.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Fetch't, let me see't.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Why, so I can, sir, but I will not now.
This is a trick to put me from my suit:
Pray you, let Cassio be received again.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Fetch me the handkerchief: my mind misgives.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Come, come;
You'll never meet a more sufficient man.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: The handkerchief!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I pray, talk me of Cassio.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: The handkerchief!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: A man that all his time
Hath founded his good fortunes on your love,
Shared dangers with you, —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: The handkerchief!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I' faith, you are to blame.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: 'Zounds! Exit.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Is not this man jealous?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I ne'er saw this before.
Sure, there's some wonder in this handkerchief:
I am most unhappy in the loss of it.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: 'Tis not a year or two shows us a man:
They are all but stomachs, and we all but food;
They eat us hungerly, and when they are full,
They belch us. Look you, Cassio and my husband! Enter CAsslo and IAGO.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: There is no other way; 'tis she must do't:
And, lo, the happiness! Go, and importune her.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: How now, good Cassio! what's the news with you?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Madam, my former suit: I do beseech you
That by your virtuous means I may again
Exist, and be a member of his love
Whom I with all the office of my heart
Entirely honour: I would not be delayed.
If my offence be of such mortal kind
That nor my service past, nor present sorrows,
Nor purposed merit in futurity,
Can ransom me into his love again,
But to know so must be my benefit;
So shall I clothe me in a forced content,
And shut myself up in some other course,
To fortune's alms.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Alas, thrice-gentle Cassio!
My advocation is not now in tune;
My lord is not my lord; nor should I know him,
Were he in favour as in humour altered.
So help me every spirit sanctified,
As I have spoken for you all my best
And stood within the blank of his displeasure
For my free speech! you must awhile be patient:
What I can do I will; and more I will
Than for myself I dare: let that suffice you.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Is my lord angry?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: He went hence but now,
And certainly in strange unquietness.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Can he be angry? I have seen the cannon,
When it hath blown his ranks into the air,
And, like the devil, from his very arm
Puffed his own brother: — and is he angry?
Something of moment then: I will go meet him:
There's matter in't indeed, if he be angry.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I prithee, do so. Exit Iago. Something, sure, of state,
Either from Venice, or some unhatched practice
Made demonstrable here in Cyprus to him,
Hath puddled his clear spirit; and in such cases
Men's natures wrangle with inferior things,
Though great ones are their object. 'Tis even so;
For let our finger ache, and it indues
Our other healthful members even to a sense
Of pain: nay, we must think men are not gods,
Nor of them look for such observancy
As fits the bridal. Beshrew me much. Emilia,
I was, unhandsome warrior as I am,
Arraigning his unkindness with my soul;
But now I find I had suborned the witness,
And he's indicted falsely.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Pray heaven it be state matters, as you think,
And no conception nor no jealous toy
Concerning you.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Alas the day! I never gave him cause.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: But jealous souls will not be answered so;
They are not ever jealous for the cause,
But jealous for they're jealous: it is a monster
Begot upon itself, born on itself.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Heaven keep the monster from Othello's mind!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Lady, amen.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I will go seek him. Cassio, walk hereabout:
If I do find him fit, I'll move your suit
And seek to effect it to my uttermost.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: I humbly thank your ladyship. Exeunt Desdemona and Emilia. Enter BIANCA.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Save you, friend Cassio!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: What make you from home?
How is't with you, my most fair Bianca?
I'faith, sweet love, I was coming to your house.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: And I was going to your lodging, Cassio.
What, keep a week away? seven days and nights?
Eightscore eight hours? and lovers' absent hours,
More tedious than the dial eightscore times?
O weary reckoning!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Pardon me, Bianca:
I have this while with leaden thoughts been pressed;
But I shall, in a more continuate time,
Strike off this score of absence. Sweet Bianca, Giving her Desdemona's handkerchief.
Take me this work out.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: O Cassio, whence came this?
This is some token from a newer friend:
To the felt absence now I feel a cause:
Is't come to this? Well, well.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Go to, woman!
Throw your vile guesses in the devil's teeth,
From whence you have them. You are jealous now
That this is from some mistress, some remembrance:
No, by my faith, Bianca.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Why, whose is it?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: I know not neither: I found it in my chamber.
I like the work well: ere it be demanded —
As like enough it will — I would have it copied:
Take it, and do't; and leave me for this time.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Leave you! wherefore?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: I do attend here on the general;
And think it no addition, nor my wish,
To have him see me womaned.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Why, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Not that I love you not.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: But that you do not love me.
I pray you, bring me on the way a little,
And say if I shall see you soon at night.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: 'Tis but a little way that I can bring you;
For I attend here: but I'll see you soon.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: 'Tis very good; I must be circumstanced. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Will you think so?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Think so, Iago!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What,
To kiss in private?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: An unauthorized kiss.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Or to be naked with her friend in bed
An hour or more, not meaning any harm?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Naked in bed, Iago, and not mean harm!
It is hypocrisy against the devil:
They that mean virtuously, and yet do so,
The devil their virtue tempts, and they tempt heaven.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: If they do nothing, 'tis a venial slip:
But if I give my wife a handkerchief, —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Why, then, 'tis hers, my lord; and, being hers,
She may, I think, bestow't on any man.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: She is protectress of her honour too:
May she give that?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Her honour is an essence that's not seen;
They have it very oft that have it not:
But, for the handkerchief, —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: By heaven, I would most gladly have forgot it.
Thou saidst — O, it comes o'er my memory,
As doth the raven o'er the infectious house,
Boding to all — he had my handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Ay, what of that?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That's not so good now.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What,
If I had said I had seen him do you wrong?
Or heard him say, — as knaves be such abroad,
Who having, by their own importunate suit,
Or voluntary dotage of some mistress,
Convinced or supplied them, cannot choose
But they must blab —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Hath he said any thing?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: He hath, my lord; but be you well assured,
No more than he'll unswear.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What hath he said?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: 'Faith, that he did — I know not what he did.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What? what?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Lie —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: With her?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: With her, on her; what you will.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Lie with her! lie on her! We say lie on her, when
they belie her. Lie with her! 'Zounds, that's
fulsome. — Handkerchief — confessions — handkerchief! — To
confess, and be hanged for his labour; — first, to
be hanged, and then to confess. — I tremble at it.
Nature would not invest herself in such shadowing
passion without some instruction. It is not
words that shakes me thus. Pish! Noses, ears,
and lips. — Is't possible? — Confess — handkerchief! — O
devil!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Work on,
My medicine, work! Thus credulous fools are caught;
And many worthy and chaste dames even thus,
All guiltless, meet reproach. What, ho! my lord!
My lord, I say! Othello! Enter CASSIO. How now, Cassio!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: My lord is fall'n into an epilepsy:
This is his second fit; he had one yesterday.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Rub him about the temples.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: No, forbear;
The lethargy must have his quiet course:
If not, he foams at mouth and by and by
Breaks out to savage madness. Look, he stirs:
Do you withdraw yourself a little while,
He will recover straight: when he is gone,
I would on great occasion speak with you. Exit Cassio,
How is it, general? have you not hurt your head?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Dost thou mock me?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I mock you not, by heaven.
Would you would bear your fortune like a man!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: A horned man's a monster and a beast.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: There's many a beast then in a populous city,
And many a civil monster.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Did he confess it?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Good sir, be a man;
Think every bearded fellow that's but yoked
May draw with you: there's millions now alive
That nightly lie in those unproper beds
Which they dare swear peculiar: your case is better.
O, 'tis the spite of hell, the fiend's arch-mock,
To lip a wanton in a secure couch,
And to suppose her chaste! No, let me know;
And knowing what I am, I know what she shall be.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O, thou art wise; 'tis certain.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Stand you awhile apart;
Confine yourself but in a patient list.
Whilst you were here o'erwhelmed with your grief —
A passion most unsuiting such a man —
Cassio came hither: I shifted him away,
And laid good 'scuses upon your ecstasy,
Bade him anon return and here speak with me;
The which he promised. Do but encave yourself,
And mark the fleers, the gibes, and notable scorns,
That dwell in every region of his face;
For I will make him tell the tale anew,
Where, how, how oft, how long ago, and when
He hath, and is again to cope your wife:
I say, but mark his gesture. Marry, patience;
Or I shall say you are all in all in spleen,
And nothing of a man.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Dost thou hear, Iago?
I will be found most cunning in my patience;
But — dost thou hear? — most bloody.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: That's not amiss;
But yet keep time in all. Will you withdraw? Othello retires.
Now will I question Cassio of Bianca,
A huswife that by selling her desires
Buys herself bread and clothes: it is a creature
That dotes on Cassio; as 'tis the strumpet's plague
To beguile many and be beguiled by one:
He, when he hears of her, cannot restrain
From the excess of laughter. Here he comes: Re-enter CASSIO.
As he shall smile, Othello shall go mad;
And his unbookish jealousy must construe
Poor Cassio's smiles, gestures and light behaviours,
Quite in the wrong. How do you now, lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: The worser that you give me the addition
Whose want even kills me.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Ply Desdemona well, and you are sure on't. Speaking lower
Now, if this suit lay in Bianca's power,
How quickly should you speed!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Alas, poor caitiff!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Look, how he laughs already!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I never knew woman love man so.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Alas, poor rogue! I think, i' faith, she loves me.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Now he denies it faintly, and laughs it out.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Do you hear, Cassio?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Now he importunes him
To tell it o'er: go to; well said, well said.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: She gives it out that you shall marry her:
Do you intend it?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Do you triumph, Roman? do you triumph?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: I marry her! what? a customer! Prithee, bear some
charity to my wit; do not think it so unwholesome. Ha,
ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: So, so, so, so: they laugh that wins.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: 'Faith, the cry goes that you marry her.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: Prithee, say true.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: I am a very villain else.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Have you scored me? Well.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: This is the monkey's own giving out: she is
persuaded I will marry her, out of her own love and
flattery, not out of my promise.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Iago beckons me; now he begins the story.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: She was here even now; she haunts me in every
place. I was the other day talking on the sea-bank
with certain Venetians; and thither comes the
bauble, and, by this hand, falls me thus about my
neck —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Crying “O dear Cassio!” as it were: his gesture
imports it.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: So hangs, and lolls, and weeps upon me; so hales, and
pulls me: ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Now he tells how she plucked him to my chamber.
O, I see that nose of yours. but not that dog I shall
throw it to.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: Well, I must leave her company.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Before me! look, where she comes.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: 'Tis such another fitchew! marry, a perfumed one.
What do you mean by this haunting of me?

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.ab: Let the devil and his dam haunt you! What did
you mean by that same handkerchief you gave me
even now? I was a fine fool to take it. I must
take out the work? — A likely piece of work, that
you should find it in your chamber, and know not
who left it there? This is some minx's token,
and I must take out the work? There; give it your
hobby-horse: wheresoever you had it, I'll take out no
work on't.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: How now, my sweet Bianca! how now! how now!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: By heaven, that should be my handkerchief!

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.ab: An you'll come to supper to-night, you may; an you
will not, come when you are next prepared for.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: After her, after her.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: 'Faith, I must; she'll rail in the streets else.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Will you sup there?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: 'Faith, I intend so.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Well, I may chance to see you; for I would very fain
speak with you.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.ab: Prithee, come; will you?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Go to; say no more.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: How shall I murder him, Iago?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Did you perceive how he laughed at his vice?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: O Iago!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: And did you see the handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Was that mine?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Yours, by this hand: and to see how he prizes
the foolish woman your wife! she gave it him, and he
hath given it his whore.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: I would have him nine years a-killing. A fine woman!
a fair woman! a sweet woman!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Nay, you must forget that.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Ay, let her rot, and perish, and be damned
to-night; for she shall not live: no, my heart
is turned to stone; I strike it, and it hurts my
hand. O, the world hath not a sweeter creature:
she might lie by an emperor's side and command him
tasks.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Nay, that's not your way.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Hang her! I do but say what she is: so delicate
with her needle: an admirable musician: O! she
will sing the savageness out of a bear: of so high and
plenteous wit and invention:

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: She's the worse for all this.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: O, a thousand, a thousand times: and then, of so
gentle a condition!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Ay, too gentle.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Nay, that's certain: but yet the pity of it, Iago! O
Iago, the pity of it, Iago!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: If you are so fond over her iniquity, give her
patent to offend; for, if it touch not you, it comes
near nobody.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: I will chop her into messes: cuckold me!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: O, 'tis foul in her.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: With mine officer!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: That's fouler.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Get me some poison, Iago; this night: I'll not
expostulate with her, lest her body and beauty
unprovide my mind again: this night, Iago.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Do it not with poison, strangle her in her bed, even
the bed she hath contaminated.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Good, good: the justice of it pleases: very good.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: And for Cassio, let me be his undertaker: you shall
hear more by midnight.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Excellent good. A trumpet within. What trumpet is that same?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I warrant, something from Venice. 'Tis Lodovico
This comes from the duke: see, your wife's with him. Enter LODOViCO, DESDEMONA, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: God save you, worthy general!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: With all my heart, sir,

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: The duke and the senators of Venice greet you. Gives him a letter.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I kiss the instrument of their pleasures. Opens letter, and reads.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: And what's the news, good cousin Lodovico?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I am very glad to see you, signior;
Welcome to Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: I thank you. How does Lieutenant Cassio?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Lives, sir.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Cousin, there's fall'n between him and my lord
An unkind breach: but you shall make all well.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Are you sure of that?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: “This fail you not to do, as you will — “

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: He did not call; he's busy in the paper.
Is there division 'twixt my lord and Cassio?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: A most unhappy one: I would do much
To atone them, for the love I bear to Cassio.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Fire and brimstone!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Are you wise?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: What, is he angry?

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: May be the letter moved him;
For, as I think, they do command him home,
Deputing Cassio in his government.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: By my troth, I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I am glad to see you mad.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Why, sweet Othello, —

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Devil!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I have not deserved this.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: My lord, this would not be believed in Venice,
Though I should swear I saw't: 'tis very much:
Make her amends; she weeps.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O devil, devil!
If that the earth could teem with woman's tears,
Each drop she falls would prove a crocodile.
Out of my sight!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I will not stay to offend you. Going.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Truly, an obedient lady:
I do beseech your lordship, call her back.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Mistress!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: My lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What would you with her, sir?

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Who, I, my lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ay; you did wish that I would make her turn:
Sir, she can turn, and turn, and yet go on,
And turn again; and she can weep, sir, weep;
And she's obedient, as you say, obedient,
Very obedient. Proceed you in your tears.
Concerning this, sir, — O well-painted passion! —
I am commanded home. Get you away;
I'll send for you anon. Sir, I obey the mandate,
And will return to Venice. Hence, avaunt! Exit Desdemona.
Cassio shall have my place. And, sir, tonight,
I do entreat that we may sup together:
You are welcome, sir, to Cyprus. — Goats and monkeys! Exit.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Is this the noble Moor whom our full senate
Call all in all sufficient? Is this the nature
Whom passion could not shake? whose solid virtue
The shot of accident, nor dart of chance,
Could neither graze nor pierce?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: He is much changed.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Are his wits safe? is he not light of brain?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: He's that he is: I may not breathe my censure
What he might be: if what he might he is not,
I would to heaven he were!

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: What, strike his wife!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: 'Faith, that was not so well; yet would I knew
That stroke would prove the worst!

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Is it his use?
Or did the letters work upon his blood,
And new-create this fault?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Alas, alas!
It is not honesty in me to speak
What I have seen and known. You shall observe him,
And his own courses will denote him so
That I may save my speech: do but go after,
And mark how he continues.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: I am sorry that I am deceived in him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: You have seen nothing then?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Nor ever heard, nor ever did suspect.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Yes, you have seen Cassio and she together.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: But then I saw no harm, and then I heard
Each syllable that breath made up between them.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What, did they never whisper?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Never, my lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Nor send you out o' the way?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: To fetch her fan, her gloves, her mask, nor nothing?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Never, my lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That's strange.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I durst, my lord, to wager she is honest,
Lay down my soul at stake: if you think other,
Remove your thought; it doth abuse your bosom.
If any wretch have put this in your head,
Let heaven requite it with the serpent's curse!
For, if she be not honest, chaste, and true,
There's no man happy; the purest of their wives
Is foul as slander.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Bid her come hither: go. Exit Emilia.
She says enough; yet she's a simple bawd
That cannot say as much. This is a subtle whore,
A closet lock and key of villainous secrets:
And yet she'll kneel and pray; I have seen her do't. Enter DESDEMONA with EMILIA.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: My lord, what is your will?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Pray you, chuck, come hither.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: What is your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Let me see your eyes;
Look in my face.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: What horrible fancy's this?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Some of your function, mistress;
Leave procreants alone and shut the door;
Cough, or cry “hem,” if anybody come:
Your mystery, your mystery: nay, dispatch. Exit Emilia.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Upon my knee, what doth your speech import?
I understand a fury in your words,
But not the words.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Why, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Your wife, my lord; your true
And loyal wife.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Come, swear it, damn thyself;
Lest, being like one of heaven, the devils themselves
Should fear to seize thee: therefore be double damned:
Swear thou art honest.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Heaven doth truly know it.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Heaven truly knows that thou art false as hell.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: To whom, my lord? with whom? how am I false?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ah Desdemon! away! away! away!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Alas the heavy day! Why do you weep?
Am I the motive of these tears, my lord?
If haply you my father do suspect
An instrument of this your calling back,
Lay not your blame on me: if you have lost him,
Why, I have lost him too.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Had it pleased heaven
To try me with affliction; had they rained
All kind of sores and shames on my bare head,
Steeped me in poverty to the very lips,
Given to captivity me and my utmost hopes,
I should have found in some place of my soul
A drop of patience: but, alas, to make me
The fixed figure for the time of scorn
To point his slow unmoving finger at!
Yet could I bear that too; well, very well:
But there, where I have garnered up my heart,
Where either I must live, or bear no life;
The fountain from the which my current runs,
Or else dries up; to be discarded thence!
Or keep it as a cistern for foul toads
To knot and gender in! Turn thy complexion there,
Patience, thou young and rose-lipped cherubin, —
Ay, here, look grim as hell!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I hope my noble lord esteems me honest.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O, ay; as summer flies are in the shambles,
That quicken even with blowing. O thou weed,
Who art so lovely fair and smell'st so sweet
That the sense aches at thee, would thou hadst ne'er been born!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Alas, what ignorant sin have I committed?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Was this fair paper, this most goodly book,
Made to write “whore” upon? What committed!
Committed! O thou public commoner!
I should make very forges of my cheeks,
That would to cinders burn up modesty,
Did I but speak thy deeds. What committed!
Heaven stops the nose at it and the moon winks,
The bawdy wind that kisses all it meets
Is hushed within the hollow mine of earth.
And will not hear't. What committed!
Impudent strumpet!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: By heaven, you do me wrong.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Are not you a strumpet?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: No, as I am a Christian:
If to preserve this vessel for my lord
From any other foul unlawful touch
Be not to be a strumpet, I am none.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What, not a whore?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: No, as I shall be saved.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: O, heaven forgive us!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I cry you mercy, then:
I took you for that cunning whore of Venice
That married with Othello. Raising his voice
You, mistress,
That have the office opposite to Saint Peter,
And keeps the gate of hell! Re-enter EMILIA. You, you, ay, you!
We have done our course; there's money for your pains:
I pray you, turn the key and keep our counsel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Alas, what does this gentleman conceive?
How do you, madam? how do you, my good lady?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Faith, half asleep.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Good madam, what's the matter with my lord?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: With who?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Why, with my lord, madam.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Who is thy lord?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: He that is yours, sweet lady.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I have none: do not talk to me, Emilia;
I cannot weep; nor answers have I none,
But what should go by water. Prithee, tonight
Lay on my bed my wedding-sheets: remember;
And call thy husband hither.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Here's a change indeed! Exit.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: 'Tis meet I should be used so, very meet.
How have I been behaved, that he might stick
The small'st opinion on my least misuse? Re-enter EMILIA with IAGO.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What is your pleasure, madam? How is't with you?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I cannot tell. Those that do teach young babes
Do it with gentle means and easy tasks:
He might have chid me so; for, in good faith,
I am a child to chiding.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What is the matter, lady?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Alas, Iago, my lord hath so bewhored her,
Thrown such despite and heavy terms upon her,
That true hearts cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Am I that name, Iago?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What name, fair lady?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Such as she said my lord did say I was.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: He called her whore: a beggar in his drink
Could not have laid such terms upon his callet.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Why did he so?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I do not know; I am sure I am none such.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Do not weep, do not weep. Alas the day!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Hath she forsook so many noble matches,
Her father and her country and her friends,
To be called whore? would it not make one weep?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: It is my wretched fortune.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Beshrew him for't!
How comes this trick upon him?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Nay, heaven doth know.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I will be hanged, if some eternal villain,
Some busy and insinuating rogue,
Some cogging, cozening slave, to get some office,
Have not devised this slander; I will be hanged else.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Fie, there is no such man; it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: If any such there be, heaven pardon him!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: A halter pardon him! and hell gnaw his bones!
Why should he call her whore? who keeps her company?
What place? what time? what form? what likelihood?
The Moor's abused by some most villainous knave,
Some base notorious knave, some scurvy fellow.
O heaven, that such companions thou'ldst unfold,
And put in every honest hand a whip
To lash the rascals naked through the world
Even from the east to the west!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Speak within door.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O, fie upon them! Some such squire he was
That turned your wit the seamy side without,
And made you to suspect me with the Moor.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: You are a fool; go to.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Alas, Iago,
What shall I do to win my lord again?
Good friend, go to him; for, by this light of heaven,
I know not how I lost him. Here I kneel:
If e'er my will did trespass 'gainst his love,
Either in discourse of thought or actual deed,
Or that mine eyes, mine ears, or any sense,
Delighted them in any other form;
Or that I do not yet, and ever did,
And ever will — though he do shake me off
To beggarly divorcement: — love him dearly,
Comfort forswear me! Unkindness may do much;
And his unkindness may defeat my life,
But never taint my love. I cannot say “whore:”
It does abhor me now I speak the word;
To do the act that might the addition earn
Not the world's mass of vanity could make me.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I pray you, be content; 'tis but his humour:
The business of the state does him offence,
And he does chide with you.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: If 'twere no other, —

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: It is but so, I warrant. Trumpets within.
Hark, how these instruments summon to supper!
The messengers of Venice stays the meat:
Go in, and weep not; all things shall be well. Exeunt Desdemona and Emilia. Enter RODERIGO.
sp.ab: How now, Roderigo!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: I do not find that thou dealest justly with me.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: What in the contrary?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: Every day thou daffest me with some device, Iago;
and rather, as it seems to me now, keepest from
me all conveniency than suppliest me with the
least advantage of hope. I will indeed no longer
endure it, nor am I yet persuaded to put up in peace
what already I have foolishly suffered.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Will you hear me, Roderigo?

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: 'Faith, I have heard too much, for your words and
performances are no kin together.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: You charge me most unjustly.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: With nought but truth. I have wasted myself out
of my means. The jewels you have had from me to
deliver Desdemona would half have corrupted a
votarist: you have told me she hath received them
and returned me expectations and comforts of sudden
respect and acquaintance, but I find none.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Well; go to; very well.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: Very well! go to! I cannot go to man; nor 'tis
not very well: By this hand, I think it is scurvy, and
begin to find myself fopped in it.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Very well.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: I tell you 'tis not very well. I will make myself
known to Desdemona: if she will return me my
jewels, I will give over my suit and repent my
unlawful solicitation; if not, assure yourself I will
seek satisfaction of you.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: You have said now.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: Ay, and said nothing but what I protest intendment of
doing.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Why, now I see there's mettle in thee, and even
from this instant do build on thee a better
opinion than ever before. Give me thy hand,
Roderigo: thou hast taken against me a most just
exception; but yet, I protest, I have dealt most
directly in thy affair.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: It hath not appeared.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: I grant indeed it hath not appeared, and your
suspicion is not without wit and judgement. But,
Roderigo, if thou hast that in thee indeed,
which I have greater reason to believe now than
ever, I mean purpose, courage and valour, this
night show it: if thou the next night following
enjoy not Desdemona, take me from this world with
treachery and devise engines for my life.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: Well, what is it? is it within reason and compass?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Sir, there is especial commission come from Venice to
depute Cassio in Othello's place.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: Is that true? why, then Othello and Desdemona return
again to Venice.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: O, no; he goes into Mauritania and taketh away
with him the fair Desdemona, unless his abode
be lingered here by some accident: wherein none can
be so determinate as the removing of Cassio.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: How do you mean, removing him?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Why, by making him uncapable of Othello's place;
knocking out his brains.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: And that you would have me to do?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: Ay, if you dare do yourself a profit and a right.
He sups to-night with a harlotry and thither
will I go to him: he knows not yet of his
honourable fortune. If you will watch his going
thence, which I will fashion to fall out between
twelve and one, you may take him at your pleasure:
I will be near to second your attempt, and he
shall fall between us. Come, stand not amazed at
it, but go along with me; I will show you such
a necessity in his death that you shall think
yourself bound to put it on him. It is now high
suppertime, and the night grows to waste: about it.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.ab: I will hear further reason for this.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.ab: And you shall be satisfied.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 3
div.stage: Enter OTHELLO, LODOVICO, DESDEMONA, EMILIA, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: I do beseech you, sir, trouble yourself no further.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: O, pardon me; 'twill do me good to walk.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Madam, good night; I humbly thank your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Your honour is most welcome.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Will you walk, sir?
sp.ab: O, — Desdemona, —

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: My lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.ab: Get you to bed on the instant; I will be returned
forthwith: dismiss your attendant there: look't be
done.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: I will, my lord.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: How goes it now? he looks gentler than he did.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: He says he will return incontinent:
And hath commanded me to go to bed,
And bade me to dismiss you.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Dismiss me!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: It was his bidding; therefore, good Emilia,
Give me my nightly wearing, and adieu:
We must not now displease him.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I would you had never seen him!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: So would not I: my love doth so approve him,
That even his stubbornness, his checks, his frowns, —
Prithee, unpin me, — have grace and favour in them.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I have laid those sheets you bade me on the bed.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: All's one. Good faith, how foolish are our minds!
If I do die before thee, prithee, shroud me
In one of these same sheets.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Come, come, you talk.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: My mother had a maid called Barbary:
She was in love, and he she loved proved mad
And did forsake her: she had a song of “willow;”
An old thing 'twas, but it expressed her fortune,
And she died singing it: that song to-night
Will not go from my mind; I have much to do,
But to go hang my head all at one side,
And sing it like poor Barbary. Prithee, dispatch.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Shall I go fetch your night-gown?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: No, unpin me here.
sp.ab: This Lodovico is a proper man.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.ab: A very handsome man.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.ab: He speaks well.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.ab: I know a lady in Venice would have walked barefoot to
Palestine for a touch of his nether lip.

sp.speaker: Desdemona

lg.l: The poor soul sat sighing by a sycamore tree,
Sing all a green willow;
Her hand on her bosom, her head on her knee,
Sing willow, willow, willow:
The fresh streams ran by her, and murmured her moans;
Sing willow, willow, willow;
Her salt tears fell from her, and softened the stones;
Sing willow,

sp.ab: Lay by these: —

lg.l: willow, willow;

sp.ab: Prithee, hie thee; he'll come anon: —

lg.l: Sing all a green willow must be my garland.
Let nobody blame him; his scorn I approve, —

sp.l: Nay, that's not next. — Hark! who is't that knocks?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.ab: It's the wind.

sp.speaker: Desdemona

lg.l: I called my love false love; but what said he then?
Sing willow, willow, willow:
If I court moe women, you'll couch with moe men. —

sp.l: So, get thee gone; good night. Mine eyes do itch;
Doth that bode weeping?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: 'Tis neither here nor there.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I have heard it said so. O, these men, these men!
Dost thou in conscience think, — tell me, Emilia, —
That there be women do abuse their husbands
In such gross kind?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: There be some such, no question.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Why, would not you?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: No, by this heavenly light!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Nor I neither by this heavenly light;
I might do't as well i' the dark.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Wouldst thou do such a deed for all the world?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: The world's a huge thing: it is a great price
For a small vice.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Good troth, I think thou wouldst not.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.ab: By my troth, I think I should; and undo't when
I had done. Marry, I would not do such a thing
for a joint-ring, nor for measures of lawn, nor
for gowns, petticoats, nor caps, nor any petty
exhibition; but, for all the whole world! Uds
pity, who would not make her husband a cuckold
to make him a monarch? I should venture purgatory
for't.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Beshrew me, if I would do such a wrong
For the whole world.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.ab: Why, the wrong is but a wrong i' the world; and
having the world for your labour, 'tis a wrong
in your own world, and you might quickly make it
right.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I do not think there is any such woman.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.ab: Yes, a dozen; and as many to the vantage as would
store the world they played for.
sp.l: But I do think it is their husbands' faults
If wives do fall: say that they slack their duties,
And pour our treasures into foreign laps,
Or else break out in peevish jealousies,
Throwing restraint upon us; or say they strike us,
Or scant our former having in despite;
Why, we have galls, and though we have some grace,
Yet have we some revenge. Let husbands know
Their wives have sense like them: they see and smell
And have their palates both for sweet and sour,
As husbands have. What is it that they do
When they change us for others? Is it sport?
I think it is: and doth affection breed it?
I think it doth: is't frailty that thus errs?
It is so too: and have not we affections,
Desires for sport, and frailty, as men have?

lg.l: Then let them use us well: else let them know,
The ills we do, their ills instruct us so.
Good night, good night: God me such uses send,
Not to pick bad from bad, but by bad mend! Exeunt,

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Here, stand behind this bulk; straight will he come:
Wear thy good rapier bare, and put it home:
Quick, quick; fear nothing; I'll be at thy elbow:
It makes us, or it mars us; think on that,
And fix most firm thy resolution.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: Be near at hand; I may miscarry in't.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Here, at thy hand: be bold, and take thy stand. Retires.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: I have no great devotion to the deed;
And yet he hath given me satisfying reasons:
'Tis but a man gone. Forth, my sword: he dies.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I have rubbed this young quat almost to the sense,
And he grows angry. Now, whether he kill Cassio,
Or Cassio him, or each do kill the other,
Every way makes my gain: live Roderigo,
He calls me to a restitution large
Of gold and jewels that I bobbed from him,
As gifts to Desdemona;
It must not be: if Cassio do remain,
He hath a daily beauty in his life
That makes me ugly; and, besides, the Moor
May unfold me to him; there stand I in much peril:
No, he must die. Be't so: I hear him coming. Enter CASSIO.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: I know his gait, 'tis he. — Villain, thou diest! Makes a pass at Cassio.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: That thrust had been mine enemy indeed,
But that my coat is better than thou know'st:
I will make proof of thine. Draws, and wounds Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: O, I am slain! Iago from behind wounds Cassio in the leg, and exit.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: I am maimed for ever. Help, ho! murder! murder! Falls. Enter OTHELLO.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: The voice of Cassio: Iago keeps his word.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: O, villain that I am!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: It is even so.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: O, help, ho! light! a surgeon!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: 'Tis he: — O brave Iago, honest and just,
That hast such noble sense of thy friend's wrong!
Thou teachest me. Minion, your dear lies dead,
And your unblest fate hies: strumpet, I come.
Forth of my heart those charms, thine eyes, are blotted;
Thy bed, lust-stained, shall with lust's blood be spotted. Exit. Enter LODOVlCO and GRATIANO.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: What, ho! no watch? no passage? murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: 'Tis some mischance; the voice is very direful.

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: O, help!

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Hark!

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: O wretched villain!

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Two or three groan: 'tis heavy night:
These may be counterfeits: let's think't unsafe
To come in to the cry without more help.

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: Nobody come? then shall I bleed to death.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: Hark! Re-enter IAGO, with a light.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Here's one comes in his shirt, with light and weapons.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Who's there? whose noise is this that cries on murder?

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: We do not know.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Did not you hear a cry?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Here, here! for heaven sake, help me!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: This is Othello's ancient, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: The same indeed; a very valiant fellow.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What are you here that cry so grievously?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: Iago? O, I am spoiled, undone by villains!
Give me some help.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: O me, lieutenant! what villains have done this?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: I think that one of them is hereabout,
And cannot make away.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: O treacherous villains!
What are you there? come in, and give some help. To Lodovico and Gratiano,

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: O, help me there!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: That's one of them.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: O murderous slave! O villain! Stabs Roderigo,

sp.speaker: Roderigo
sp.l: O damned Iago! O inhuman dog!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Kill men i' the dark! — Where be these bloody thieves? —
How silent is this town! Ho! murder! murder! —
What may you be? are you of good or evil?

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: As you shall prove us, praise us.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Signior Lodovico?

sp.speaker: Lodovico
sp.l: He, sir.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: I cry you mercy. Here's Cassio hurt by villains.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Cassio!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: How is't, brother!

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: My leg is cut in two.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Marry, heaven forbid!
Light, gentlemen: I'll bind it with my shirt. Enter BIANCA.

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: What is the matter, ho? who is't that cried?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Who is't that cried!

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: O my dear Cassio! my sweet Cassio!
O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: O notable strumpet! Cassio, may you suspect
Who they should be that have thus mangled you?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: I am sorry to find you thus: I have been to seek you.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Lend me a garter. So. O, for a chair,
To bear him easily hence!

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: Alas, he faints! O Cassio, Cassio, Cassio!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Gentlemen all, I do suspect this trash
To be a party in this injury.
Patience awhile, good Cassio. Come, come;
Lend me a light. Know we this face or no?
Alas, my friend and my dear countryman
Roderigo! no: — yes, sure: — O heaven! Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: What, of Venice?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Even he, sir: did you know him?

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Know him! ay.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Signior Gratiano? I cry your gentle pardon;
These bloody accidents must excuse my manners,
That so neglected you.

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: I am glad to see you.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: How do you, Cassio? O, a chair, a chair!

sp.speaker: Gratiano
sp.l: Roderigo!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: He, he, 'tis he. A chair brought in.
O, that's well said; the chair.
Some good man bear him carefully from hence;
I'll fetch the general's surgeon. To Bianca
For you, mistress,
Save you your labour. He that lies slain here, Cassio,
Was my dear friend: what malice was between you?

sp.speaker: Cassio
sp.l: None in the world; nor do I know the man.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: What, look you pale?
O, bear him out o' the air. Cassio and Roderigo are borne off.
Stay you, good gentlemen. Look you pale, mistress?
Do you perceive the gastness of her eye?
Nay, an you stare, we shall hear more anon.
Behold her well; I pray you, look upon her:
Do you see, gentlemen? nay, guiltiness will speak,
Though tongues were out of use. Enter EMILIA.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Alas what is the matter? What is the matter, husband?

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Cassio hath here been set on in the dark
By Roderigo and fellows that are scaped:
He's almost slain, and Roderigo quite dead.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Alas, good gentleman alas, good Cassio!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: This is the fruits of whoring. Prithee, Emilia,
Go know of Cassio where he supped to-night. To Bianca
What, do you shake at that?

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: He supped at my house; but I therefore shake not.

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: O, did he so? I charge you, go with me.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O fie upon thee, strumpet!

sp.speaker: Bianca
sp.l: I am no strumpet; but of life as honest
As you that thus abuse me.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: As I! foh! fie upon thee!

sp.speaker: Iago
sp.l: Kind gentlemen, let's go see poor Cassio dressed.
Come, mistress, you must tell's another tale.
Emilia, run you to the citadel,
And tell my lord and lady what hath happed.
Will you go on afore? Aside
This is the night
That either makes me or fordoes me quite. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 2
div.stage: A bedchamber in the castle: DESDEMONA in bed asleep; a light burning.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: It is the cause, it is the cause, my soul, —
Let me not name it to you, you chaste stars! —
It is the cause. Yet I'll not shed her blood.
Nor scar that whiter skin of hers than snow,
And smooth as monumental alabaster.
Yet she must die, else she'll betray more men.
Put out the light, and then put out the light:
If I quench thee, thou flaming minister,
I can again thy former light restore,
Should I repent me: but once put out thy light,
Thou cunning'st pattern of excelling nature,
I know not where is that Promethean heat
That can thy light relume. When I have plucked thy rose,
I cannot give it vital growth again,
It needs must wither: I'll smell thee on the tree. Kissing her.
Ah, balmy breath, that dost almost persuade
Justice to break her sword! One more, one more.
Be thus when thou art dead, and I will kill thee,
And love thee after. One more, and that's the last:
So sweet was ne'er so fatal. I must weep,
But they are cruel tears: this sorrow's heavenly;
It strikes where it doth love. She wakes.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Who's there? Othello?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ay, Desdemona.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Will you come to bed, my lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Have you prayed to-night, Desdemon?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: If you bethink yourself of any crime
Unreconciled as yet to heaven and grace,
Solicit for it straight.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Alas, my lord, what may you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Well, do it, and be brief; I will walk by:
I would not kill thy unprepared spirit;
No; heaven forfend! I would not kill thy soul.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Talk you of killing?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ay, I do.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Then heaven
Have mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Amen, with all my heart!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: If you say so, I hope you will not kill me.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Hum!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: And yet I fear you; for you're fatal then
When your eyes roll so: why I should fear I know not,
Since guiltiness I know not; but yet I feel I fear.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Think on thy sins.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: They are loves I bear to you.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ay, and for that thou diest.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: That death's unnatural that kills for loving.
Alas, why gnaw you so your nether lip?
Some bloody passion shakes your very frame:
These are portents: but yet I hope, I hope,
They do not point on me.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Peace, and be still!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: I will so. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That handkerchief which I so loved and gave thee
Thou gavest to Cassio.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: No, by my life and soul!
Send for the man, and ask him.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Sweet soul, take heed,
Take heed of perjury; thou art on thy deathbed.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Ay, but not yet to die.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Yes, presently:
Therefore confess thee freely of thy sin;
For to deny each article with oath
Cannot remove nor choke the strong conception
That I do groan withal. Thou art to die.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Then Lord have mercy on me!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I say, amen.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: And have you mercy too! I never did
Offend you in my life; never loved Cassio
But with such general warranty of heaven
As I might love; I never gave him token.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: By heaven, I saw my handkerchief in's hand.
O perjured woman! thou dost stone my heart,
And makest me call what I intend to do
A murder, which I thought a sacrifice:
I saw the handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: He found it then;
I never gave it him: send for him hither;
Let him confess a truth.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: He hath confessed.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: What, my lord?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That he hath used thee.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: How? unlawfully?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Ay.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: He will not say so.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: No, his mouth is stopped;
Honest Iago hath ta'en order for't.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: O! my fear interprets: what, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Had all his hairs been lives, my great revenge
Had stomach for them all.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Alas! he is betrayed and I undone.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Out, strumpet! weep'st thou for him to my face?

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: O, banish me, my lord, but kill me not!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Down, strumpet!

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: Kill me to-morrow: let me live tonight!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Nay, an you strive, —

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: But half an hour!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Being done, there is no pause.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: But while I say one prayer!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: It is too late.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: O Lord! Lord! Lord!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: My lord, my lord! what, ho! my lord, my lord!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What noise is this? Not dead? not yet quite dead?
I that am cruel am yet merciful;
I would not have thee linger in thy pain:
So, so.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: What, ho! my lord, my lord!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O, good my lord, I would speak a word with you!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Yes: 'tis Emilia. By and by. She's dead.
'Tis like she comes to speak of Cassio's death.
The noise was high. Ha! no more moving?
Still as the grave. Shall she come in? were't good? —
I think she stirs again: — no. What's best to do?
If she come in, she'll sure speak to my wife:
My wife! my wife! what wife? I have no wife.
O, insupportable! O heavy hour!
Methinks it should be now a huge eclipse
Of sun and moon, and that the affrighted globe
did yawn at alteration.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: I do beseech you
That I may speak with you, O, good my lord!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: I had forgot thee: O, come in, Emilia:
Soft; by and by. Let me the curtains draw.
Where art thou? Unlocks the door. Enter EMILIA. What's the matter with thee now?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O, my good lord, yonder's foul murders done!

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: What? now?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: But now, my lord.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: It is the very error of the moon;
She comes more nearer earth than she was wont,
And makes men mad.

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Cassio, my lord, hath killed a young Venetian
Called Roderigo.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Roderigo killed!
And Cassio killed!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: No, Cassio is not killed.

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: Not Cassio killed! then murder's out of tune,
And sweet revenge grows harsh.

sp.speaker: Desdemona
sp.l: O, falsely, falsely murdered!

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: O Lord, what cry is that?

sp.speaker: Othello
sp.l: That! what?

sp.speaker: Emilia
sp.l: Out, and alas! that was my lady's voice.
